article.title: Flux rope, hyperbolic flux tube, and late EUV phases in a non-eruptive circular-ribbon flare

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the quasi-circular ribbon in Figure 1 primarily trace?
choices: Footpoints of the spine lines.
Footpoints of the fan separatrix surface.
Location of the null point.
Footpoints of the HFT.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the sequential evolution of peaking times in the 211 Å, 193 Å, and 171 Å emissions during each EUV late phase suggest?
choices: Additional heating in the late-phase loops.
Differential cooling of post-flare loops of different lengths.
Reconnection at the null point is occurring in multiple episodes.
A combination of additional heating and differential cooling.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the right panel of Figure 3 demonstrate?
choices: The distribution of the line of sight magnetic field.
The co-spatiality between the chromospheric ribbons observed at 1600 Å and the separatrix footpoints.
The presence of a twisted flux rope below the fan surface.
The connectivity of the QSL-halo surrounding the fan and spine separatrices.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the red iso-contours of high-Q in Figure 4b indicate?
choices: Regions where the magnetic field is weak.
Regions where magnetic reconnection is likely to be associated with actual flare ribbons.
The location of the flux rope.
The presence of brightenings observed prior to null-point reconnection.

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the pink lines in Figure 5 represent?
choices: Field lines belonging to the fan separatrix.
Field lines belonging to the outer spine QSL-halo.
Low-lying internal QSLs confined below a flux rope, forming an HFT.
Field lines belonging to the flux rope.
